Models in Django

Posted on Oct 3, 2023

Models

A model is the single, definitive source of information about your data. It contains the essential fields and behaviors of the data you’re storing. Generally, each model maps to a single database table.

The Basics

  • Each model is a python class or Subclass.
  • The attributes of models represents a Data Field.
  • For e.g following model defines a Student which has f_name & rollNo :
  • from django.db import models
    class Person(models.Model):
     f_name = models.CharField(max_length=30)
     rollNo = models.IntField(default=0)

Defining a Model

  • To start working on models first of all you have to create a Django project for it.
  • Read our blog to start Django App.
  • After creating app navigate to directory containing Models.py file.
  • In this file you can define the structure of your data using Python classes.
  • Refer above example for creating student model.

Creating Migrations

  • After creating your model you must have to migrate it.
  • Django provides a migration system that allows you to create database tables based on your models. To create migrations for your app, run:
    python manage.py makemigrations appname
  • After creating migrations, apply them to the database:
    python manage.py migrate

Registering Models with the Admin Panel

Django's admin panel is a powerful tool for managing your application's data. To make your model accessible via the admin panel, open appname/admin.py and register your model like this:
from django.contrib import admin
from .models import Post
admin.site.register(Post)

Running the Development Server

  • To see your project in action, start the development server by running:
    python manage.py runserver
  • Create Super User using this command:
    python manage.py createsuperuser
  • Navigate your project on Localhost:
    http://localhost:3000/
  • Navigate your admin dashboard on Localhost:
    http://localhost:3000/admin
  • Enter your details and good to go.
